Speciation is whatever you say it is.
No. There are several definitions, depending on the context. Wildlife biologists and paleontologists use different definitions. Probably the most common modern definition used by biologists is the Biological Species Concept (BSC) defined by Ernst Mayr in 1942.
 
Darwin said the Galapogos Finches were seperate species because they could not interbreed.
Nope. Darwin said no such thing. Darwin thought that the birds he collected were all a single species. It was actually Owen, a respected scientist who was still clinging to the biblical creation story, who pointed out that there were several species. Since Darwin didn't think it would matter, he didn't specify when and where he had collected his specimens. Thus, he convinced Capt. Fitzroy (also a believer in biblical creation), who had done a better job of tagging his specimens, to give his collection of finches to Owen for study. Owen classified the birds into several species, not Darwin. Further, the reasons for dividing the specimens into several species had nothing to do with ability to interbreed since the birds were all dead. The initial classification was based on morphology.
 
They can , Darwin was wrong.
As I pointed out, Darwin never made the claim so he wasn't wrong. Besides, just the statement that interbreeding makes two organisms the same species is ignorant. There are lots of species that can interbreed with closely related species. For example, lions and tigers are both members of the same genus and they can interbreed. However, they do so only in captivity since the wild populations are reproductively isolated. The same is true of polar bears and brown bears. In the case of Darwin's finches, they are usually reproductively isolated. However, on rare occasions some of the closely related species have been observed to interbreed. But a blanket statement that Darwin's finches can interbreed is either ignorant or dishonest. Generally, they cannot. Experiments that encouraged interbreeding among various species failed. The would not interbreed. On those rare occasions when it was observed, the two species observed were in the same genus. A Geospiza scandens was observed to interbreed with a G. fortis. I have only heard of interbreeding between two other species.
 
I know evolutionist claim that if animals that could formerly interbreed can no longer do so it proves the common ancestor fairy tale. All it proves is they can no longer interbreed. It is absurd .
So you are claiming that a single species that splits into populations that can no longer breed did not have a common ancestor species. Do you ever actually think about what you are saying? Mostly your posts are incoherent.

 Peddler - how would you explain the similarities in homologous proteins across species? Ones involved in critical areas and close to being perfect catalysts hardly change at all, while others have conserved regions based around active sites and important structural areas though often there will be different amino acids with very similar properties. Evolution told us to expect this, and its what was found (mutations that affect important regions of proteins are not generally beneficial and will not be conserved, mutations can crop up in non essential regions and only alter the behaviour slightly).
 
 Evolution is such an important part of molecular biology we would have no chance at working out the structures for anywhere near as many enzymes and proteins if it were not true. Why are the predictions evolution makes proved time and time again here?

Granted, cosmology doesn't have anything to do with evolution. Does that prevent us from pointing out how stupid these articles are? It does not!
 
 First link: People are making guesses, therefore there was no big bang.
 
 Science is all about making guesses. You observe something, and try to explain it. Does your guess make sense, does it fit the data? Yes? Then we'll run with it until someone comes up with a better hypothesis. No? Then throw it out and try again. We can't wait for the answers to be handed to us; the only option we have is to make our best guess and see how well it works.
 
 Second link: Some stars are close, therefore there was no big bang
 
 "singularity of belief that compels astronomers to turn a blind eye to the wrong end of their telescopes while ignoring disagreements with what they imagine they see"
 That mangling of the English language should, in and of itself, disqualify the article as a source of intelligent opinion. Leaving that aside, all the article really says is that cosmology isn't done yet. The science can't explain everything. Duh! We don't even have the tools to gather the data to even begin to pretend that we could answer all the questions yet. Does this mean that everything we have learned is wrong, that we must discard the notion of an ancient universe and grasp a 6000 year old universe to our metaphorical busom? Again, duh. There are details to iron out, and unanswered question, and things yet to learn, but there isn't the tiniest itty bittiest crunb of doubt that the age of the universe should be measured in billions of years, not thousands. Certainly nothing in that article would give anyone any reason to believe otherwise.
 
 Third link: A star is moving fast, therefore yada yada yada
 
 Classic mistake non-scientists make. There's a data point outside the curve predicted by science. Is the cause A) science is completely wrong, or B) something unusual caused the abberant data point?
 Not only is the answer B (need I say duh again), but we even know what the unusual event was. When solar systems or galaxies collide, you often get a gravitational "slingshot" effect. We've used this effect to get greater velocities for our deep space probes. Pass close to another massive body and you shoot off in a new direction at a greater speed. This star's speed and trejectory are the result of such an event.
 
 The rest of the links are from the same site, and show the same degree of integrity. I'll shoot them down if anyone wants, but I think the point has been made. All of the sites Peddler sited are more than willing to sacrifice truth and integrity to push their religious/political agenda.

 If I may respond to that as well.
 
 Every time a child is born, it's different than both parents. That's evolution. Change. Are you suggesting some mythological god had a role, or are you you a little more advanced and understand how human reproduction works on a basic level?
 
 Bacteria, a better example, can actually swap genetic material, and "evolve" rapidly, without even needing to go through a sexual reproductive cycle.
 
 Just do a simple web search and I'm sure you'll learn some science..i.e. facts about reality.
 
 http://uanews.opi.arizona.edu/cgi-bin/WebObjects/UANews.woa/wa/SRStoryDetails?ArticleID=3669
 
Bacteria can easily swap genes by direct transfer of genetic material from one cell to another, even between bacteria that are only distantly related. This well-known phenomenon allows harmful bacteria to react quickly to new host defenses, and to share their new counter-defenses with each other - witness for example the rapid spread of antibiotic resistance among bacteria.

 
 Of course, we don't even need to get that complex, try the flu:
 
 

 1. Influenza viruses evolve rapidly. 
 
 Flu viruses mutate and evolve rapidly. (In fact, it has been estimated that the proteins of the influenza virus evolve as much as a million times faster than most human proteins!) For this reason, so new and slightly different viral strains appear all the time. The differences among these new strains often include changes in coat proteins. Therefore, any immune system memory cells produced by a vaccination or previous infection no longer recognize the new strains. When that happens, the immune response must mount a defense from scratch, and the viruses have enough time to make the host sick.
 
 If you think about this, you can probably see how our immune response creates a form of natural selection that drives the evolution of these viruses. Here's why. Strains that don't change their coat protein are stopped by the immune response before they can spread. These strains, therefore, have substantially lowered fitness, and are effectively wiped out. Strains that change their coat proteins, on the other hand, have higher fitness. These strains delay the immune response long enough to make us sick - which forces us to spread the virus to new hosts by coughing and sneezing
. 
 
 Or perhaps our own immune system response to bacteria and viruses?
 
 Are you sure you know what "evolution" means, because if you are suggesting viruses change by acts of god, and not through simple laws of physics, then I think you're missing something when you read/listen/process information. How much energy have you devoted to understanding the physics behind biological life? If you do devote a little time to it, you'll find a whole lot of great information and resources out there.
 
 -Mach

 You call this fairy tales yet the fact that some man did it isn't fairy tale? We can't prove for sure any origin of the universe so let's say this man did it. Not trying to attack religion merely imitate his style of argument. Evolution isn't the same as just the study of speciation, or creation of species. Evolution does not in itself actually create new species. This occurs mainly from genetic mutations. Evolution is the study of how species change over time mainly through natural selection and the ancestors of each species. One main line of evidence (not an observation yet, I'll get to it) is that there are many similarities between our genetics and other animals. As you trace further and further back to single-celled organisms and back you still have about 80% of the genes the same.
 
 Now you demand observations:
 Someone already mentioned the finches in the Galapagos. I'm not exactly sure on the details but I do know that they evolved separately and their traits both helped them to survive in their particular environment.
 
 Another observations is creatures such as rabits in a forest. There have been countless experiments that have found that when they had creatures such as rabits in a forest with natural predators, later almost all of them had darker fur (this is after a few generations) because the lighter ones had been eaten and couldn't reproduce. That's evolution.

Every time a child is born, it's different than both parents. That's evolution. Change.
Biological evolution, the kind that is explained by the theories of evolution, is more than just change. It is a specific kind of change. Evolution is a change in the allele frequency in a population over generations. So the changes that are evolution are those across the entire population AND those changes must be passed on the the following generation. The mere birth of a single individual who may never survive to reproduce doesn't change the allele frequency.

No, you are mistaken. Evolution is concerned with the change in allele frequency over time. The age of the Universe is irrelevent.

The age of the Earth is a significant piece of evidence in support of evolution. The age of the Universe is irrelevent.

Of course it can. We have observed evolution happening many times.
 
 
If the earth was only a million years old it could not have happened.
If you were only three days old, you wouldn't be able to read and write. You can, so you are more than three days old. Life evolved, so the Earth is more than "only a million years old". These are self evident facts.
 
 
The age of the earth is decided by committee and doubles approx. every 25 years.
Incorrect. The estimated age of the Earth approximately doubled every 20 years between 1850ish and 1980. It hasn't changed since 1980 and is extremely unlikely to change significantly ever again.

Simple question then Peddlar, given that we have observed speciation in animals and a massive amount of variation in dogs - why is it so hard to accept that the two might have happened together? You end up with a creature that can't breed with the original species you bred it from and looks very different.

Incorrect. The estimated age of the Earth approximately doubled every 20 years between 1850ish and 1980. It hasn't changed since 1980 and is extremely unlikely to change significantly ever again.

 And it wasn't by committee.
 
 The age of the Earth kept increasing because people kept radio-dating older and older rocks.
 
 http://nuclearweaponarchive.org/Usa/Med/Dawnage.html
 
 In 1905 Rutherford and Boltwood used the ratio between radioactive isotopes and their decay products to data a rock to 500 million years old.
 
 The age of the Earth jumped again in 1907 when Boltwood identified a piece of uraninite as being 1.64 billion years old.
 
 I'd call that a triple jump in 2 years.
The age of the Earth, as I learned it, was dated by the Moon.

And it wasn't by committee.
 
 The age of the Earth kept increasing because people kept radio-dating older and older rocks.
 
 http://nuclearweaponarchive.org/Usa/Med/Dawnage.html
 
 In 1905 Rutherford and Boltwood used the ratio between radioactive isotopes and their decay products to data a rock to 500 million years old.
 
 The age of the Earth jumped again in 1907 when Boltwood identified a piece of uraninite as being 1.64 billion years old.
 
 I'd call that a triple jump in 2 years.
Very good point. It is also worth pointing out that 500 million to a billion years would be ample time for life to have evolved from nothing to what we see today. So this non existant committee could have simply fixed the age in 1907 and declared their job done. But as you say, it is not determined by committee, but instead is determined by experiment. As such it was bound to climb in arbitary jumps until the correct date was reached.
